variant.question:
You are making an approach to an airfield when you receive this windshear warning:
"Wind over the airfield is 160/05kts, wind to the north-east is 060/25kts"
What is most likely to be the cause?

options.text: A downburst near the airport
A cold front passing the airfield is causing the wind to veer.
An active anticyclone over the airfield
A weak warm front passing the airfield is causing the change in the wind direction

variant.question: An aerodrome warning message gives information, among other things, about..

options.text: TS; SN including the expected or observed snow accumulation; hoar frost.
PL; SS; RA.
DS; SN clearing; FZRA including the observed braking action.
GR; FG; FZRA including the observed friction coefficient.

A message issued by a meteorological office concerning the meteorological conditions which could adversely affect aircraft on the ground, including parked aircraft, and the aerodrome facilities and services.

A message prepared by a meteorological office concerning wind shear which could adversely affect aircraft on the approach or take-off path, or during a circling approach, between the runway level and a specified upper level, and aircraft on the runway during the landing roll or take-off run.
A message issued by a meteorological watch office concerning the occurrence and/or expected occurrence of specified en-route weather phenomena, which may affect the safety of aircraft operations.
The part of a METAR message that is called supplementary information.

A message issued by a meteorological office concerning the meteorological conditions which could adversely affect aircraft on ground, including parked aircraft, and the aerodrome facilities and services.
A message issued by a meteorological watch office concerning the occurrence and/or expected occurrence of specified en-route weather phenomena, which may affect the safety of aircraft operations.

A message prepared by a meteorological office concerning wind shear which could adversely affect aircraft on the approach path or take-off path or during circling approach between runway level and a specified upper level, and aircraft on the runway during landing roll or take-off run.
The part of a METAR message that is called supplementary information.

A message issued by a meteorological office concerning
the meteorological conditions which could adversely affect aircraft
on ground, including parked aircraft, and the aerodrome facilities
and services.

A message issued by a meteorological watch office
concerning the occurrence and/or expected occurrence of specified
en-route weather phenomena, which may affect the safety of aircraft
operations.

A message prepared by a meteorological office concerning
wind shear which could adversely affect aircraft on the approach
path or take-off path or during circling approach between runway
level and a specified upper level, and aircraft on the runway
during

The part of a METAR message that is called supplementary
information.

variant.question: How often shall the information produced by an airfield windshear alert system be updated?

options.text: Every minute.
Every hour.
Every 30 minutes.
Every 15 minutes.

variant.question:
Airport 1, WS WRNG ALL RWY.
Airport 2, WS WRNG ALL RWY.
Airport 3, WS WRNG RW18.
Airport 4, WS WRNG RW18.
Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Aerodrome 1, wind shear.
Aerodrome 4, downburst.
Aerodrome 2, downburst.
Aerodrome 3, wind shear.

variant.question:
Following an alert received from the Low Level Wind Shear Alerting System (LLWSAS), ATC informs the crew of an aircraft on approach:

"Wind shear alert, centre-field wind 150 at 12, north-east boundary wind 060 at 25." (The centre-field wind is obtained from an anemometer approximately in the middle of the airfield, the north-east boundary wind from a different anemometer near that location). How should this message be interpreted?

options.text: The change in wind direction and speed may indicate an active downburst.
A weak warm front is passing the airfield, causing a shift in wind direction and speed.
An active anticyclone over the airfield is causing a marked backing of the wind from centre field to the boundary
A cold front moving east is causing a marked veering of the wind from centre field to the boundary.

variant.question: An aerodrome wind shear alert should be updated every..

options.text: minute
hour
30 minutes
15 minutes

variant.question:
Following an alert received from the Low Level Wind Shear Alerting System (LLWSAS), ATC informs the crew of an aircraft on approach 'Wind shear alert, centre-field wind 150 at 12, north-east boundary wind 060 at 25.' (The centre-field wind is obtained from an anemometer approximately in the middle of the airfield, the north-east boundary wind from a different anemometer near that location)
 How should this message be interpreted?

options.text: The change in wind direction and speed may indicate an active downburst.
A cold front moving east is causing a marked veering of the wind from centre field to the boundary.
An active anticyclone over the airfield is causing a marked backing of the wind from centre field to the boundary
A weak warm front is passing the airfield, causing a shift in wind direction and speed.
